content.title: Access to electricity and clean cooking (SDG 7.1)
content.intro: M1: Introduction to Sustainable Energy System Transformation | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1

content.text: Lesson 1 Overview

The goal of ensuring universal access to affordable, reliable, and modern energy services, such as electricity and clean cooking services, appliances and fuels, is framed within SDG 7.1. Its interconnectedness with various goals offers synergies to address multiple global challenges simultaneously, amplifying opportunities for poverty reduction, gender equality, education, health, food security and economic development.

content.title: Key Concepts
content.intro: Explore foundational ideas from this lesson.

concepts.title: clean cooking
concepts.body: Clean cooking refers to the use of safe, efficient, and environmentally friendly cooking technologies and fuels that reduce indoor air pollution and minimize health risks, while also lowering greenhouse gas emissions.

concepts.title: energy and health
concepts.body: The relationship between energy consumption, production, and its impact on human health, including how energy systems affect air quality, access to clean water, and overall well-being.

concepts.title: sdg synergies
concepts.body: SDG synergies refer to the interconnected benefits and positive interactions that occur when efforts to achieve one Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) also support the achievement of other SDGs, leading to more effective and holistic progress in sustainable development.

content.text: SDG Target 7.1

By 2030, ensure universal access to affordable, reliable and modern energy services Indicators 7.1.1 Proportion of population with access to electricity 7.1.2 Proportion of population with primary reliance on clean fuels and technology

content.intro: M1: Introduction to Sustainable Energy System Transformation | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 1
content.title: Part 1: Maximizing Synergies in Sustainable Energy Access

content.text: Part 1 Overview

Maximizing synergies in sustainable energy access involves leveraging connections between SDG 7.1 (ensuring universal access to affordable, reliable, and modern energy services) and other Sustainable Development Goals. This approach aims to create integrated solutions that simultaneously advance energy access while supporting goals like poverty reduction, improved health, gender equality, and climate action.

content.intro: M1: Introduction to Sustainable Energy System Transformation | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 1 | A
content.title: A. Enlightening Education

content.text: Well-lit, heated, and cooled schools, work spaces and households create comfortable, safe and effective learning spaces for children and adults (SDG 4). Access to affordable, reliable, and modern energy in schools significantly improves education quality and accessibility. Electricity access in educational setups extends education opportunities into evening classes, catering to diverse schedules. Modern information and communication technologies (SDG 9), powered through electricity access, significantly enhance learning experiences and foster digital literacy. Furthermore, access to the Internet supports digital connectivity of rural schools, which during COVID-19 has been key for educational resilience. In addition, electricity facilitates the provision of Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) services, which are particularly important for girls and adolescent girls, as access to these services is linked to lower dropout rates. Consequently, access to quality education results in enhanced educational attainment and high completion rates, providing lifelong benefits to children.

content.intro: M1: Introduction to Sustainable Energy System Transformation | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 1 | B
content.title: B. Enhancing Health Services and Water Access

content.text: Access to reliable electricity is fundamental for health services (SDG 3), including safe childbirth, vaccinations, diagnostics, and emergency response. Nearly 1 billion people in low- and lower-middle-income countries lack reliable electricity in healthcare facilities (WHO, 2023). Electricity enables rural populations to store and refrigerate medicines and vaccines, ensuring community health. It powers vital medical devices, lighting and communications. Furthermore, the lack of reliable energy contributes to indoor air pollution, as many rely on biomass or kerosene for cooking and lighting, leading to respiratory and cardiovascular diseases, particularly affecting women and children. Electricity is also key for improving household health conditions, through clean indoor environments, cooking facilities, and thermal comfort (heating and cooling). Energy also contributes to expanding water and sanitation services (SDG 6), particularly in water-stressed regions. Energy also contributes to expanding water and sanitation services (SDG 6), particularly in water-stressed regions. Decentralized solar PV water pumps can replace more expensive diesel pumps, and mini-grids can power filtration technologies, such as reverse osmosis systems, to produce clean drinking water (IEA, 2023), powering a shift toward unconventional water supply options (e.g., desalination). Electricity is essential in health facilities, powering medical devices, refrigeration for vaccines, and providing access to clean water and sanitation, which are vital for public health. Solar PV systems and solar pumps installed by UNICEF (Box 1) have been used successfully in healthcare facilities to improve access to safe water and hygienic sanitation.

In 2019, UNICEF’s Solar-powered water systems program installed more than 1,200 solar-powered water systems in over 40 countries across six regions, providing water to the most vulnerable children and their families in remote areas. The initiative deployed renewable energy access solutions prioritizing public service facilities such as health facilities, schools, and community centers. In Nigeria, 371 systems helped provide water and power to 52 schools and 85 health-care facilities, and large-scale solar-powered systems were implemented in Afghanistan, Somalia, South Sudan and Yemen in emergency contexts (source: UNICEF).

content.intro: M1: Introduction to Sustainable Energy System Transformation | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 1 | C
content.title: C. Improving Food Security and Productive Development

content.text: Providing affordable, reliable, and modern energy services to the world's poor aligns with poverty eradication and reducing inequalities (SDG 1 and SDG 10). In rural areas, where many lack energy access, empowering smallholder farmers with energy facilitates groundwater pumping, mechanization of farming, and maintenance of temperature-controlled supply chains. This enhances food crop yields, diversifies regional diets, contributes to income generation (SDG 2 and SDG 8) and strengthens food security. The World Bank Group projects that by 2030, two-thirds of the world’s extreme poor will live in fragile, conflict and violence settings. As a result, achieving SDG 2 (Zero Hunger) and SDG 10 (Reduce Inequalities) demands innovative and integrated solutions. The adoption of solar-powered irrigation systems in Yemen is an example of an innovative and conflict-resilient practice that has safeguarded food production capacities (Al-Eryani, 2022). Box 2 below briefly describes the World Bank Group's solar project in Yemen.

Between 2018 and 2022, the Yemen Emergency Electricity Access Project (YEEAP) spearheaded the expansion of electricity access in rural and peri-urban areas through solar solutions. This World Bank-funded initiative, executed by the United Nations Office for Project Services (UNOPS) alongside local entities, empowered six microfinance institutions to introduce financing products for small-scale energy systems. Over 3.2 million people, notably 51% female, accessed critical services like water, education, and healthcare, including support for COVID-19, through solar-powered facilities (source: World Bank Group).

content.intro: M1: Introduction to Sustainable Energy System Transformation | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 1 | D
content.title: D. Energizing Gender Equality

content.text: Indoor air pollution is estimated to cause around 13 deaths per minute, mostly affecting women and girls who shoulder household responsibilities and face exposure to polluting lighting and cooking methods (SDG 3 and SDG 5). Women and girls are believed, in some regions, to be spending up to 18 hours weekly on wood gathering and household cooking (UNDP, 2022). Therefore, access to clean energy directly aids in reducing women's time poverty, for instance thanks to equipment such as fridges and washing machines, better educational attendance is attained. Access to energy fundamentally equates to access to opportunity. Yet, unless progress accelerates, by 2030 an estimated 341 million women and girls will still lack electricity. Studies indicate a 9 to 23% increase in women's employment post-electrification (UN, 2022). Public outdoor lighting increases security for women and girls, allowing more autonomy after dark and reducing exposure to gender-based violence. Similarly, information technologies and the Internet can help reduce the digital divide and foster digital inclusion for women and girls (WEF, 2023; ITU, 2020). Empowered women are more likely to drive local initiatives benefiting from cleaner cooking and lighting, which directly impacts their lives and families. UNDP’s integrated projects in India and Nepal have shown promising results toward energy access, women’s equality and productive opportunities development (Box 3). UN Women's efforts in Ethiopia, included interest-free loans and entrepreneurship training benefiting over 19,500 women, enabling them to invest in an energy-saving cooking stove cooperative (Box 4). It is essential to recognize that women are not just beneficiaries of sustainable energy solutions, but are critical actors and leaders in the energy transition. Women comprise 40% of the solar PV workforce, nearly double their participation in the oil and gas sectors of only 22%. Similarly, the clean cooking sector offers unique opportunities, as women represent half of managers in both bioethanol and electricity-powered cooking. Supporting women through investments and inclusive policies is therefore crucial, acknowledging their exceptional resilience and determination in breaking barriers and overcoming gender biases.

UNDP's energy access projects have significantly bolstered livelihoods, particularly for women, increasing income potential by up to 2.5 times. In India's Jharkhand State, solar stations facilitated by the UNDP have empowered women-run micro-enterprises, enabling them to produce essential hygiene products while earning an income. Similarly, in Nepal's Solta Bazaar, a solar minigrid supported a health lab and an IT training center, providing crucial services and education, sparing women long journeys for medical care (source: UNDP Climate).

The UN Women-Joint Programme, initiated in Ethiopia in 2011, unites six UN agencies to bolster gender equality and women's empowerment. With a focus on all 11 regions, it aligns with Ethiopia's development frameworks, aiming to enhance women's income, education, and rights while promoting leadership. Supported by Sweden and Norway, the program includes interest-free loans and business skill development, creating a revolving fund for women's empowerment. Notably, the initiative has enabled women, to invest in an energy-saving cooking stove cooperative, fostering economic empowerment within their village and beyond (source: UN Women).

content.intro: M1: Introduction to Sustainable Energy System Transformation | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 2
content.title: Part 2: Overcoming Trade-offs

content.text: Part 2 Overview

Managing trade-offs in sustainable energy access involves carefully balancing competing priorities and potential negative impacts when pursuing SDG 7.1 and related goals. This approach recognizes that actions to improve energy access may sometimes conflict with other sustainability objectives, requiring thoughtful decision-making and mitigation strategies.

content.intro: M1: Introduction to Sustainable Energy System Transformation | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 2 | A
content.title: A. Balancing Affordability and Sufficiency

content.text: Increased access to affordable, reliable energy can inadvertently foster wasteful water consumption and overexploitation of resources, known as the "rebound effect". Energy sufficiency and affordability pose challenges in transitioning to clean energy technologies, potentially leading to a return to polluting energy sources. A similar dilemma arises in clean cooking: high upfront costs and unreliable LPG supply hinder rural communities from abandoning biomass (UCL, 2021). For instance, unconventional water supply options such as desalination are highly energy-intensive (ICSU, 2017), and this demand for energy can inadvertently exacerbate resource depletion. Similarly, certain agricultural practices that rely on energy-intensive technologies could also lead to unsustainable water use or land degradation. To mitigate these rebound effects, strategies such as energy sufficiency (ensuring that energy is used efficiently without waste), affordability mechanisms (making energy solutions financially accessible without overconsumption) and capacity-building (educating and training communities on sustainable energy use and conservation) have shown promise. (WBG, 2017; WLPGA, 2018). Box 5 provides an example of a project in Somalia that addressed multiple issues by bolstering sustainable energy security and livelihoods at the same time.

The United Nations Joint Program for Sustainable Charcoal Reduction and Alternative Livelihoods (PROSCAL) ran from 2016 to 2022 with the objective of reducing unsustainable charcoal production, trade, and usage in Somalia. It sought to bolster energy security and livelihoods by engaging stakeholders, enforcing trade bans on the use of charcoal, developing alternative energy, transitioning charcoal practices, and promoting reforestation. The project promoted fuel-efficient stoves, invested in liquid petroleum gas, and introduced Mogadishu's first biogas project to reduce demand for charcoal inside Somalia. PROSCAL's interventions aimed to create local economic opportunities, diminish poverty, halt environmental degradation, improve energy security, foster resilience among vulnerable groups, diversify energy sources, mitigate conflict, and promote peace and development (source: UNDP).

content.intro: M1: Introduction to Sustainable Energy System Transformation | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 2 | B
content.title: B. Ensuring Sustainable Battery Value Chains

content.text: Renewable-based energy access solutions, such as solar or wind, heavily rely on batteries to overcome natural resources’ intermittence. However, mining, manufacturing, inappropriate maintenance and disposal of batteries can lead to pollution, impacting human health (SDG 3) and ecosystems (SDG 14-15) as well as present social risks. With the demand for batteries going up in recent years, effective waste management is becoming increasingly important. Stakeholders and companies must prioritize a robust commitment to proper battery management, covering maintenance, security standards, and disposal. E-waste regulation planning is becoming integral to operational plans, fostering innovation and strategic partnerships, especially in regions lacking e-waste infrastructure. For example, only a few countries in sub-Saharan Africa (including Rwanda, Nigeria, Kenya and South Africa), have e-waste management facilities, equipped for off-grid solar value-chain recycling, and cross-boundary movement is expensive and complex. The scarcity of e-waste management facilities capable of handling end-of-life products from off-grid solar requires immediate attention and action (Lighting Global, 2022). The Global Battery Alliance (GBA) (Box 6) has emerged to tackle these challenges. In their recent report, Off-Grid Solar Market Trends Report 2022: State of the Sector, the Alliance highlights the need for pilot projects aimed at launching and scaling effective corporate reverse logistics programs. Additionally, GBA advocates for establishing traceability and disclosure systems to address these critical issues.

The Global Battery Alliance (GBA), initiated at the World Economic Forum in 2017, aims to ensure a sustainable battery value chain by 2030 through a collective effort involving international organizations, NGOs, industry, academia, and governments. This alliance focuses on Action Partnerships, tackling critical areas like establishing global criteria for sustainable batteries, ensuring responsible sourcing of materials, and promoting energy access in emerging economies while emphasizing circular practices to reduce lead poisoning and environmental impacts (source: GBA). In parallel, the surge in critical mineral demand raises pressing concerns about fairness and sustainability, including the environmental impacts of land degradation, water scarcity, and the well-being of local communities. To address these challenges, the UN Panel on Critical Energy Transition Minerals’ guide —Resourcing the Energy Transition— calls for justice and equity to anchor this transition. A truly sustainable energy future must balance technological progress with social and ecological responsibility, ensuring that communities and ecosystems are protected throughout this critical shift.

content.intro: M1: Introduction to Sustainable Energy System Transformation | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 2 | C
content.title: C. Reaching Last-Mile Communities

content.text: Remote communities lacking grid access, marked by low population density, low-income levels, challenging terrains, and poor infrastructure, confront significant hurdles in accessing electricity. These communities can be grouped into three categories: geographically remote regions like rural settings, mountainous areas, small islands, and deep forests; communities with a remote chance of gaining grid access, including displaced refugees due to conflict or natural disasters; and those fully dependent on off-grid energy with minimal demand profiles, such as Indigenous communities. Despite varying characteristics, these settlements share commonalities in low electricity access, economic and energy poverty, and the difficulty of obtaining grid-based electricity supply (IRENA, 2023). The diverse profile of last-mile communities necessitates community-centric models to ensure tailored solutions that fit their unique characteristics and needs. For example, successful and inclusive projects in the Hindu Kush Himalaya region (Box 7) showcase effective approaches addressing the challenges of last-mile regions (HIMAP, 2019; ADB, 2023).

Through an intervention called “Creating Self Sustainable, Smart and Low Carbon Villages”, the Global Himalayan Expedition (GHE) is helping remote Himalayan communities lacking electricity access to transform through locally designed, locally implemented and locally maintained solutions. Their aim is to bring about holistic change by merging the elements of sustainability, clean cooking, digital education, homestay tourism and solar grid. Being connected with a solar grid gives villages a future and protects their cultural heritage (source: GHE).

content.intro: M1: Introduction to Sustainable Energy System Transformation | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 2 | D
content.title: D. Promoting Gender Inclusivity in Energy Access

content.text: Social norms and gender roles can hinder women from benefiting equally from energy access initiatives, discourage them from participating in the sector’s labor force, and impacting their inclusion in decision-making processes. Gender-blind initiatives counteract women's equality, worsening gender gaps in energy poverty (SDG Action, 2023). Affordability mechanisms that neglect women deepen dependency, as they often receive lower salaries and depend on men's income. The focus should be on how access to electricity reduces the amount of time women and girls spend on unpaid domestic work, or time poverty, freeing up time for income-generating activities or education, thus enhancing their empowerment and economic opportunities. Women are particularly vulnerable in conflict, disaster, and emergency settings, with millions forcibly displaced, lacking access to modern lighting and facing risks like violence and fuel-related challenges. The lack of gender-responsive training for off-grid systems can lead to the exclusion of women, reinforcing gender inequalities. The creation of an enabling environment for women's participation in the energy sector requires gender-responsive planning, policymaking, regulation, and progress tracking through gender-disaggregated data collection and analysis (UN, 2021). Providing access to STEM education for women and girls is crucial, enabling them to compete for jobs in the renewable energy sector and become active participants and agents of change. This approach can lead to improvements in clean energy access deployment and management.

content.title: Key Takeaways
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

takeaways.title: Energy access initiatives must prioritize inclusivity and gender equality to avoid reinforcing existing inequalities. Empowering women and marginalized groups through targeted training, financial mechanisms, and participation in energy decision-making fosters equitable benefits and accelerates progress in achieving universal energy access.

Expanding energy access must be balanced with sustainability considerations, including mitigating resource overexploitation, managing rebound effects, and ensuring proper maintenance and disposal of renewable energy components such as batteries.

Reliable and clean energy access catalyzes progress across multiple Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), enhancing education, health, food security, gender equality and economic development. Integrated solutions, such as solar-powered water systems and decentralized energy infrastructure, can address energy poverty while promoting resilience in underserved communities.
